States
------

The space is sufficiently large to reveal many of elements of a
$C^*$-algebra.

[**Theorem 1-**]{} We have that

-   $S(\mathcal{A})$ separates points, i.e. $x= 0$ if and only if
    $\phi(x) = 0$ for all $\phi \in S(\mathcal{A})$.

-   $x$ is if and only if $\phi(x) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all
    $\phi \in S(\mathcal{A})$.

-   $x$ is positive if and only if $\phi(x) \geq 0$ for all
    $\phi \in S(\mathcal{A})$.

-   If $x$ is , then $\phi(x) = \|x\|$ for some
    $\phi \in S(\mathcal{A})$.

Pure states
-----------

The pure state space is also sufficiently large to the of Theorem 1.
Hence, we can replace $S(\mathcal{A})$ by $P(\mathcal{A})$, or by any
other family of linear functionals $F$ such that
$P(\mathcal{A}) \subset F \subset S(\mathcal{A})$, in the previous
result.

-   $P(\mathcal{A})$ separates points, i.e. $x= 0$ if and only if

    $\phi \in P(\mathcal{A})$.

-   $x$ is positive if and only if $\phi(x) \geq 0$ for all
